Award.AwardTitle: Simulating Galaxies Across Reionization: A Multiwavelength View
Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-1108700
Cen

Observations indicate that the cosmological reionization history may be quite complex, and to understand at a fundamental level how the universe was reionized and what reionized it, requires a satisfactory understanding of the formation of galaxies during the reionization epoch. Current and future observations are, and will be, detecting many galaxies in the reionization epoch above redshift six, and interpreting this rich dataset will require a comprehensive theoretical framework for galaxies in halos of tens of millions to ten billion solar masses, constructed as much as possible ab initio and from first principles in the standard cold dark matter model. This research program will establish such a framework by carrying out ultra-high-resolution, cosmological, adaptive mesh refinement radiation-hydrodynamic simulations focusing on galaxies in the right mass range, combining a detailed physical treatment with sophisticated post-simulation analysis. The work will significantly advance the fields both of galaxy formation at high redshift and of cosmological reionization.

These research activities will be integrated into the training of graduate and undergraduate students, and will feed into an effective outreach program that improves the scientific understanding of the general public about cosmological research. The demands of carrying out these simulations push technological advances in supercomputers and related hardware and software, and drive the development of national research infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major activities:
We have carrried out ultra-high resolution hydrodynamic simulations of galaxy formation with major improvement in numerical implementation of major physical processes, with respect to supernova feedback process.


Specific objectives:
Our specific objectives include characterizing and understanding the major physical processes governing formation of dwarf galaxies at the epoch of reionization and the origin of globular clusters.

Significant results ---
1) We have performed an important analysis on the role of negative radiativefeedback from resident stars in minihaloes. This analysis is analytic butprovides a necessary physical gradient for high redshift galaxy formation.It is found that the most effective mechanism to suppress star formationis provided by infrared photons from resident stars via photodetachmentof H-. It is shown that a stringent upper bound on (total stellar mass,metallicity) of (1000 Msuns, -3.3+-0.2) in any minihalo can be placed. This has both important physical ramifications onformation of stars and supermassive black seeds in atomic cooling haloesat high redshift and direct consequences on the faintend galaxy luminosity function at high redshift and cosmological reionization.The luminosity function of galaxies at the epoch of reionization may besubstantially affected due to the combined effect of a diminished roleof minihaloes and an enhanced contribution from Population III starsin atomic cooling haloes. 

 

2) We have performed an analysis of the physics-rich endgame of reionizationat z=5.7, jointly utilizing the observations of the Lyα forest, the meanfree path (mfp) of ionizing photons, the luminosity function of galaxie , and new physical insight. We find that an upper limit on electron optical depth provides aconstraint on the minimum mfp (of ionizing photons) that is primarilydue to dwarf galaxies, which in turn yields a new, yet strongest constraint on the matter power spectrum on 1e6-1e9 Msun scales. With the latest Planck measurements of electron optical depth oftaue = 0.055 plus/minus 0.009, we can place an upper limit of(8.9e6, 3.8e7, 4.2e8) solar masses on the lower cutoff mass of thehalo-mass function, or equivalently, a lower limit on warm dark matterparticle mass greater than (15.1, 9.8, 4.6) keV or on sterile neutrinomass greater than (161, 90, 33) keV at the (1, 1.4, 2.2) sigma confidencelevel, respectively.


3) We have investigated the formation of metal-poor globular clusters (GCs) at the center of two atomic cooling dark matter halos at epoch of reionization using ultra-high resolution (0.1pc) cosmological radiation-hydrodynamics simulations. We find that very compact (<1 pc) and massive (6e5 Msun) globular clusters form rapidly. Becausethe local free-fall time of dense star-forming gas is very short (<<1 Myr). The simulatedclusters closely resemble the local GCs in mass and size but show ametallicity spread that is much wider than found in the local GCs. It is encouraging that a naive blind (not tuned) cosmological simulation presentsa possible channel for the formation of at least some massive GCs.

Key outcomes or Other achievements:
1) Demonstration of cosmological formation of globular clusters in dwarf galaxies at epoch of reionization


2) A joint constraint by electron scattering optical depth by CMB observations and Lyman alpha forest provides the strongestyet constraint on warm dark matter particles

undergraduate students took part in REU program related to the project.


How have the results been disseminated to communities of interest?
nothing to report

 


Participants:

The software program SCORTH has been made available to the community.

What is the impact on the development of human resources?
trained several students to conduct scientific research at the early stage in their careers.

What is the impact on physical resources that form infrastructure?

Our simulations are a drive development and advancement of computing facilities nationally and in home institutions.
